hints_html: Remember that the slope of the tangent line is the same as the derivative at the given point.
hints_latex:
Remember that the slope of the tangent line is the same as the
derivative at the given point.
hints_raw: Remember that the slope of the tangent line is the same as the derivative at the given point.
question: 1 (d)
sols_html:
Using the hint, we find the derivative at the given point. Applying the chain rule we find

\[\begin{aligned} y &= \ln\left(x^2\right) \\ \frac{dy}{dx} &= \frac1{x^2} \cdot 2x \\ \frac{dy}{dx} &= \frac2{x} \\ \left.\frac{dy}{dx}\right|_{x = e^{2}} &= {\color{blue} \frac{2}{e^{2}}}\end{aligned}\]

Using the hint, we find the derivative at the given point. In the first step below, we use our logarithm rules to see that \(\ln(x^{2}) = 2\ln(x)\). Hence

\[\begin{aligned} y &= \ln(x^{2})\\ y &= 2\ln(x)\\ \frac{dy}{dx} &= \frac{2}{x}\\ \left.\frac{dy}{dx}\right|_{x = e^{2}} &= {\color{blue} \frac{2}{e^{2}}}\end{aligned}\]
statement_html: Find the slope of the tangent line to \(\displaystyle y = \ln(x^2)\) at \(\displaystyle x = e^2\).
statement_latex:
Find the slope of the tangent line to $\displaystyle y = \ln(x^2)$ at
$\displaystyle x = e^2$.
statement_raw: Find the slope of the tangent line to <math>\displaystyle y = \ln(x^2)</math> at <math>\displaystyle x = e^2</math>.
